dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Wells, I’m Lloyd Stanton. My colleague Henry Andrews. Wells puts on a smile and shakes hands.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Come on back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanton and Andrews take seats at one end of the conferen table. Wells stands uncomfortably alone at the other end.

dialogues.text: What can we do for you?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Aren't we waiting for Clive?

dialogues.text: Mr. Coleman is tied up in a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: No offense boys, but I was supposed to be meeting with Clive.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: None taken. But, if you were supposed to be meeting with Clive you'd be meeting with Clive. That stung. Wells takes just a moment to recover. Sits. S a smile on his face and slides documents across the table

dialogues.text: .-.-Mr. Wells, Washoe has a practical value hovering just above zero. Your debt load is untenable and you come to us with raw land, no infrastructure, no fungible assets. You can’t possibly expect us to underwrite this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m talking about a small offering here. If you’ll just look at the geo you'll see what I see, which is money. Stanton looks him in the eye. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Not our money. He closes the documents with an air of finality.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can’t help you, Mr. Wells.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: These are jackpot, gentlemen. You back away from these - these are career changing opportunities. Stanton rises from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse us.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I want to talk to Clive! Wells stands, his already red face flushing, every broken capillary showing like battle scars. WELLS (CONT’D) My father put Clive Coleman on the map. He built this goddamn bank!

dialogues.text: You are not your father, Mr. Wells. Like a dagger. Wells stands stunned by the statement.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: WELLS

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .--So this salesman goes up to a house and knocks on the front door. It's opened by a ten year-old boy who has a lighted cigar in one hand, a glass of whiskey in the other and a Penthouse magazine tucked under his arm. Salesman: "Hello son. Is your mom or dad home?” The little boy: "What the fuck do you think?" Wells laughs loud. A BARMAN mixes their drinks. Acosta ta his, glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: So, Kenny, what are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Ring of fire, Mike. Ring of fire. Acosta gives a little laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You're playing my greatest hits, now. Fire’s gone out of that one.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  19.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Ring of fire hasn’t been proven. It’s the opinion of my fellow esteemed geologists that the whole thing is, quoting here, a crock of shit. Wells takes a moment, the wheels turning, then...

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Well, what the hell? You called it wrong, what are you gonna do? Acosta shoots a look.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: In this game there is no right or wrong, there’s only hits and misses.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: So, you still think you’re right?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’m right. I know I’m right. There’s gold here.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I’m happy you said that, Mike. I truly am. I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: I hate to dash your hopes, but don’t you think others have come along before you, with the same thought and, from the looks of it, deeper pockets?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Ring of fire is real. I knew it the minute I heard it. It was like a lightning strike. I never forgot it. Acosta laughs. He can’t help it. WELLS (CONT’D) Go ahead and laugh. I’m used to it. But hear this, I don’t just believe, I know.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: No one will back me on this one. Wells mixes them both two more strong ones.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I will. I’11 get the money.  20.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You look like you had to rob someone to get here.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Tell me where you want to dig, Mike, and I’1l make sure the bills are paid.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You roll in here like we’re old pals? I’m a mirage, mate. You know jack shit about who I am.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You know it’s out there. I can see it in your eyes. You still believe. As Wells says this, we can see Acosta start to believe, m for the first time in a while. WELLS (CONT’D) I get it. I was born on the side of a mountain, too. My father scraped everything he had out of the rocks. He died with dirt under his fingernails. I intend to do the same. Acosta just might be wavering. Wells won’t let him get aw WELLS (CONT’D) This business wrote me off years ago, and maybe you’re not running a hot hand... Let’s prove ‘em wrong. Prove all of them wrong. And you know why? ‘Cause Ring of Fire is right. Tell me I’m crazy, I’1ll be on the next plane. Acosta is inscrutable. Wells waits, sweating. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You're crazy. Acosta rises from the table. He tosses cash down and brus past, leaving Wells like a raft with a hole in it.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you have a hat? DISCOVER Acosta has stopped behind Wells with a kind of t is the dumbest thing I'll ever do expression.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got a hat.  21. But Wells is starting to smile.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Good. I’m taking you upriver.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What river is that, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: The only one that matters. Acosta walks out. Wells drains his drink. And WE GO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fishing village on market day. Talking birds, snake gaz and WELLS, weekend sporty, exiting a cab. The DRIVER yell points toward the river. Everyone wants to sell him somet He sees Acosta waiting by a traditional freighter canoe w the long-shaft outboard. The boatman, OBB, smokes a cigar

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You're late. This is Obb. Wells eyes the boat warily.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: That thing gonna make it?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Let’s hope so. (messing with him) Ever seen a Borneo pit viper?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Well I tell you, Mikey, I feel like I’ve met a few --

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Drop out of the trees. Good swimmers, no bigger than this... (hands 12 inches apart) But if one gets you, find a phone, call your loved ones. Wells looks around. A few native faces. Huts. No phones.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (re: their boat) I went on the exact same thing once at Weeky-Watchee. Wells hops on the freighter canoe, rocking the shit out o  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obb pulls away from the pier. Wells watches “civilization disappear behind a bend. And suddenly DAYAK TRIBESMEN pan for gold. In 300 yards, they’ve gone 5000 years back in t

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: The Dayak have been panning this river for thousands of years. That’s how it got it’s name, “Daya Kensana.” Acosta lets that hang there, like a tease.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Daya Kensana?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: The word, Daya, actually means upstream... Kensana means gold. Wells can’t contain his smile.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Upstream Gold?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: That’s its name.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You gotta be shittin’ me. If I had invented it, I wouldn’t have had the balls to name it that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natives pass in a canoe going the other way; wildlife alo the shore; ANGLES from shore, poo rafts next to clothes washing next to teeth brushing. Wells staring. A snake dr and swims through the water. Wells coolly lights a cigare RISE UP TO SEE the freighter canoe tiny with a white wake river golden in color, bisecting an endless green canopy. Wells POVs. Sun and jet lag. The steady buzz of the prop. Peering from under his hat, water rolling by. His eyes fi it, then shut. Then Acosta is shaking him awake. River narrower and darker under overhanging trees.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boatman pulls up at a muddy bank. A faint trail goes into jungle. Acosta hops ashore and Wells follows.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: So, listen... the Dayak are warrior people. Probably best known for Ngayau... headhunting.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: They believe all of a man’s power is centered in his head. So they take the head. Doesn’t happen much anymore, but they're probably around thinking we’re traders or someone’s mother-in-law. Suddenly Wells freezes. There are FACES in the leaves, watching them. Then Wells realizes Acosta has vanished up dense trail. Wells nearly runs after him. Acosta stands. He has attached a heavy coconut to the end bamboo stick. He tests its weight on the ground. THUMP. T sets out again. Thump Thump Thump.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1ll bite. What is that?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: It makes the king cobras and pythons think an elephant is coming. Wells watches every footfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light filters from high in the canopy. THUMP THUMP THUMP. coconut vibrates the earth. Wells follows, drenched in sw He stops.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Getting a world-class case of crotch rot back here. (continues, then) Jesus... How long..?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Forty million years. For the geology to cook. Then we come along and take it.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I meant --

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: I know what you meant, Wells. But imagine being asked to give up something you've been hoarding for 40 million years? This jungle will test you, Wells. Hold you up, weigh you, and decide your worth within an ounce.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Do you always talk like this? Like a book on tape.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: I suppose I do. Do you listen to books on tape, Wells? Ken Fol-let... Louis L'Amour... Ed-gar Rice Bur-roughs? He’s really made a meal of those pulp names.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Where are we going, Acosta? A no look point back over his shoulder --

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Up. I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Up? How far up?  24A.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Six, seven miles tops. Watch your step. Wells looks up. If there’s a way, only Acosta can see it.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta emerges from the foliage into a clearing. Wells struggles up after -- Acosta stands on the edge, staring out like a man who’s c home. Wells is bent over, sucking air, drowning in sweat.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Take a look. Wells looks out and is instantly spellbound -- it’s JUST HIS DREAM. GOLDEN LIGHT sparkles over a pristine valley. KENSANA RIVER snaking around, smoke from a small village the river far in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: My God, it’s just like my dream.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: There have been a few folks up here tapping over the years but they’ve all focused on the foothills far to the south, drawn by the basalt overlay. He points to an area on the opposite side of the valley. ACOSTA (CONT’D) What interests me is the other way, on the east bank, up from the river. That small depression, like a giant left a footprint walking away. Far away we see limestone features we will recognize from “Washoe site.” True excitement in Acosta’s voice -- ACOSTA (CONT’D) Those limestone structures are 300 million years old, the pale color comes from skeletons of tiny sea creatures. But the placer gold I’ve recovered there is much older. Something happened there, Wells. Something hot and angry. That’s where we'll find the tasty bits. But Wells is barely listening. He’s transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: My dream... It’s out there...  26.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Damn right it is. Two men together, staring out at their destiny, and WE GO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small village on the river. A vendor scoops rice onto f leaves, grilling some kind of meat over an open fire. He the two portions up on a flat board. Wells goes for his wallet. Acosta stops him, producing a pouch. He removes a pinch of GOLD DUST, sprinkles it on a scale on the vendor’s cart.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Coin of the realm around here. (beat) When you think about it, Gold is utterly useless. Copper, Iron, Beryllium, Palladium, Bismuth, these are metals you can do something with. But the one that’s good for nothing is the one that everybody wants. Does have a quality though. When you hold it in your hand, it does something to you. Weights are adjusted, a little more dust -- no one can ta their eyes off the sparkling gold.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Like get you to spend your whole life looking for it.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: .»+.so the lease is currently held by a Brazilian company. Acosta sits comfortably, eating. Wells searches his pocke finds a couple of mini-bar bottles of scotch, and a packe airplane peanuts. Offers one of the bottles to Acosta.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Only chance you got of surviving what’s in that bowl of microbes.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: ...-They’re looking to unload it cheap - getting buried on some Kazakh venture. Wells finds some peanuts from the plane. Eats them.  27.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You know, Mikey, I’m starting to love how you talk. And the first thing I’m gonna do is move some paper.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: None of the big guys will touch us. In Wells we see a touch of the old confidence returning.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You want to raise money from the big boys, from Harvard endowment or some pension fund, I am not your guy. But the little guys, the guys you’ve never heard of... those are my guys. How much do we need?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Seven, seven-fifty to start. Ouch... Wells takes a beat to re-focus.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: But how much are we gonna need?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: It’s not just the lease. We must first procure a permit, which in Indonesia means lining pockets. There are capital costs, too. Equipment. You don’t just do this with a couple shovels and a pick-axe.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I‘’1l get the money. Whatever it takes. Wells is about to wipe his face with his NAPKIN, but has sudden idea. He pulls out a pen and quickly scribbles something down on it then slides the napkin over to Acost

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: A contract. Read it. Sign it. Acosta looks over what Wells has written on the napkin. T share a look -- a moment. WE DON’T SEE WHAT’S ON THE NAPK

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Fair enough.  28.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: We got a deal? Acosta signs and sticks his hand out to Wells. They shake

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: For the first time in my life, I was selling something I believed in. I could feel it in my bones. Wells up, remembering the energy. Reveal more of the spac pastiche of several eras, kind of a luxury camp mixed wit whorehouse. WELLS (CONT’D) Any real salesman will tell you...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Wells, please sit down. The voice belongs to PAUL JENNINGS, early 40s, buttoned-d shirt, conservative suit, but a fun tie that was probably gift. A tape recorder is on the table. Two other men, BAN and LEVINE, both 30's, skeptical, watch as Wells takes hi seat again.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: ...If you believe it, you can sure as shit sell it.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: (braying into the phone) Hell yeah it’s risky... Bobby Burns standing mid-pitch.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m being straight here. But hey, no risk, no reward, right? It’s the usual crowd, but the mood is electric. Everyone’ working the phones, telling versions of the same story.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Acosta! Largest copper strike in history. Yeah, that guy. We got him --  29.

dialogues.speaker: NEVINS
dialogues.text: Platinum resume. Pla-ti-num. Oxford. MIT. That’s right: The Copper King --

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: Kin-sana. Indonesia. It literally means River of Gold. No, I’m not fucking kidding. Camera finding Wells AT THE BAR with his own phone, takin snippets of the phone pitches.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) It’s a 20k minimum buy-in and shares are flying off the shelf. Kay, passing with a tray of drinks, as Kenny tries to pul over. She shrugs out of his grasp and continues on. WELLS (CONT’D) Babe, this is fucking crazy --

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: Going like hotcakes. Hotcakes! Connie covering the mouthpiece, interrupts over --

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m batting 500. BabeFuckingRuth. Every other call, Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Keep throwing the line. (into phone) The best. What’d I tell you? The best. (calling to Kay) Babe, shine those dancing shoes, get ‘em ready -- She flips him off. It’s not a forever anger, but she’s an

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We don’t even have the exploration rights. What are they selling?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: They’re selling the story, Mike. And right now, the story is you. Hey, speaking of which, what are you doing?  29A.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m down in Kupang City, looking at coring equipment.  30.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (yelling to the guys) Acosta’s in Kupang City looking at coring equipment. The sales pitch shifts, Kupang City. Special coring equip

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Coring rigs will come from Kupang City. I'll put you down for 20. Two shares. You got it.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) You're magic. And as WE LOOK over this makeshift trading floor in full action, the SOUND OF KEYS BEING PUNCHED rises above the d sales chatter -- TAPE PRINTOUT SCROLLING, and WE ARE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Burns bangs figures into an ADDING MACHINE. Wells circles. It’s been a long day, everyone’s exhausted. Burn scrolls the tape, tears it off with a flourish. Passes it Wells, who reads, swallows hard, then delivers the number

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Two hundred sixty seven thousand, four hundred and thirty-four dollars. Over the phone, there’s SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta checks out new equipment while on a portable phone

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Not exactly the number I had in mind. Realize Acosta is now looking at the USED EQUIPMENT YARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta stands looking up at rusting industrial dinosaurs against the endless blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I might be able to borrow a little bit against it. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Truth. That's it for now. Can you make it work?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: That’ll get us the permit, a few holes. If we work fast and get lucky, who knows...

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Get us a little good news and we'll raise more money. Suddenly hear some DUDES AT A FOOSBALL TABLE loudly ARGUI over PAC-10 football, drowning out Wells.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You work out of a bar, Wells?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Keeping a lid on expenses, Mike. Makin’ the dollar holler. Acosta hanging up, wondering just what he’s gotten himsel into. He examines a well-used drill, speaks Bahasa with t mining equipment salesman, haggling. INT. KAY’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT A suitcase on the bed. Wells sorta packing, a haphazard undertaking under the best of circumstances. He takes a d Surveys the possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Which tie? This one or this one? Reveal Kay behind him, drink in hand.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I want my watch back.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: First off, it’s your mother’s and second you’re gonna get it back.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It was my mother’s until she gave it to me.  32-32A.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I gotta bring my good shoes, where are my good shoes?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Look under the bed. I don’t like to see my stuff up in pawns, Kenny. You know I’m sensitive to it. He gets down to look under the bed. See his ass sticking

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: We always talk about our dreams, about the ranch, clean air, big views, our place above it all. That’s what I’m doin’, getting us out of this shitbox.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I don’t mind this shitbox. He’s back up with the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: See, right there, that’s what I love -- you're like one of those booster rockets that helps us get up to the stars. Stands back with the shoes. He wiggles the shoes. WELLS (CONT’D) Too much?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: What the fuck, Kenny?

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We figure shit out together, Kenny. Through thick and fuckin’ thin. If you needed my watch, I'd give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I know, babe. I‘’1l be back soon, I promise. He starts off... Then pauses like he remembers one last t WELLS (CONT’D) Oh, here -- why don’t you time me? He dangles her mother’s watch. Turns, smiling. She smiles too. Love rushes in, overflows.  32-32AA.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Wear the blue tie. It brings out your eyes.  33. As we PRE-LAP a CALL TO PRAYER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crossing river traffic reveals a luxury hotel amid minare Super: JAKARTA, INDONESIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta goes over paperwork, shaved, hair groomed, transfo Wells, adjusting his blue tie, comes out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: What’s that smell?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I dropped a goose.  33A.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: And are you wearing cologne?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Yeah, why? You getting turned on?  34.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Listen to me: we have one shot at this. He’s the Minister of The Interior of Indonesia. If he doesn't like us for any reason, we’re done. Never put your hands on your hips. Crossing your arms is considered aggressive. And cologne, here, is an insult.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You get a whiff of some of the folks around here? I might suggest changing the national cologne policy.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: We get the deal. We don’t insult. We don’t talk. We listen, we get our permit and we get out. Are we clear?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: «.-yeah. Got it.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Now go wash it off. Wells stands there for a moment like a humiliated child. goes back into the bathroom. Off Acosta, WE GO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A formal room with a Chinese theme. Seated at the table i MINISTER OF MINING. A cadre of security and yes-men flank The Minister speaks with a cultured Indonesian accent.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: .-.I have reviewed your permit request for the Kensana property... As a waiter pours hot liquid into small bowls at each set we find Wells perspiring in his bad suit. He picks up his and starts to sip his “tea.” Acosta clears his throat -- sees the Minister dipping his fingers into his bowl.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Acosta) There is a conspicuous lack of documentation.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Hey, we've got the paperwork -- The Minister ignores him as Acosta jumps in.  34aA.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Yes, excellency. We have reports from previous attempts, but judged it best not to waste your valuable time. The Minister accepts this, but still ignores Wells.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: (beat, to Acosta) What makes you think you will find what others before you could not?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: They were looking in the wrong place. The underlying geology is sound. GIANT PRAWNS are placed in front of them. Wells can’t hel  34A.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Hey, can I get a fork? The waiters don’t move. Acosta and the Minister ignore We  35.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: There’s gold there, Excellency. And with your blessing, we will find it. A long beat. Wells gets uncomfortable. Realizes his arms crossed. Uncrosses them. And sells.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Mike really knows his stuff. There’s no one better... The Minister doesn’t even look at Wells, addressing Acost

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: As you know, our natural resources are a divine inheritance of all the people.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: As is your capable stewardship, Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: A heavy responsibility to be sure. Wells fidgets, then barks to a waiter --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Hey! Who’s a guy gotta bang to get a drink around here? Wells definitely has the Minister’s attention now.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: I am a Muslim, sir. I do not drink.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I’m an American and I do. And last time I checked, I’m hosting this little shindig, so you might want to at least acknowledge I’m sitting here.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: You are most definitely an American.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: It's the belief that paying for lunch is a substitute for manners.  36.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You're right. And I apologize. I can see I’ve offended your delicate moral sensibilities. But I may have just the thing to help you get over it. And with that, he pulls out a THICK WAD OF CASH from his jacket, sets it down on the lazy Susan with a THUD. And t spins it -- the cash rotates around the large table towar Minister. The Minister stares at Wells with contempt. WELLS (CONT’D) Now that you mention it, I’ve been thinking of converting to Muslim.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Even if we don’t find any gold, at least I still get the forty virgins--

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Wells --!

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I’m not greedy. I'll go half--twenty’s a windfall. Hell, if they’re really virgins, two would probably kill me. The cash slowly stops revolving. The Minister never looks it. He stands, throws down his napkin, and, entourage in sweeps imperiously from the restaurant. Acosta looks at Wells, his anger and disbelief palpable. he grabs up the cash and goes. Wells is alone, his face flushed with embarrassment. He sees a patron staring at h WELLS (CONT’D) What the fuck are you looking at? Wells pours himself a cup of tea, hand shaking as he drin Then he looks up and sees Acosta coming back. Wells stand about to apologize, but before he can speak -- CRACK! Acosta decks him. Wells falls backwards over the chair, hitting the floor. He looks up at Acosta standing over hi and, in a flash, recognizes just how much this matters to that much of his poise is a kind of cover. WELLS (CONT’D) You gonna tell me what happened? Wells gets up, brushing himself off. Acosta takes his tim  37. WELLS (CONT’D) I’m sorry, I couldn’t hear you.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: He took the money. A smile spreads across Wells's face.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Of course he took the money. It’s money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INFINITE JUNGLE in an anamorphic frame. Every leaf and bl of grass swaying in the wind. Then Acosta appears. This i Wells’s POV. He hurries to stay close. ACOSTA stops moving. He looks at Wells. He looks down. We approaches cautiously and also looks down. Acosta makes a in the soil. Now reveal a small army of NATIVE WORKERS waiting. A FORE shrieks and they break into motion... clearing the “giant footstep” for the first drill position at the “Washoe sit The sky is blue, dotted with white clouds; the river spar gold surrounded by the limestone cliffs. Tight shots of assembly, metal to metal. Acosta busy. Wel in his Loman suit slapping at Mosquitos, jungle pressing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A METAL SCAFFOLD lyrically sways above the grass, framed against the limestone cliffs. A break in the grass sudden reveals a WATER BUFFALO pulling the first drill. The drill is positioned. Jungle has been beaten back. A GIRL leads a goat out of a watchful crowd to the drill a Dayak “BORETN” waits. He murmurs prayers in his languag Then pulls a knife and, without hesitation or sentimental draws it across the goat’s neck -- AN ARM YANKS THE PULL-CORD on the drill, ROARING to life Panning NATIVE FACES to find WELLS as a gentle SUN SHOWER begins to rain down.  38.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: See, ahh... That’s beautiful! The sky is blessing us. Acosta stares up at the sky with a different perspective.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Monsoon’s coming early.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Monsoon? CRACK! FLASHES OF LIGHTING. Wells's face realizing the seriousness. THUNDER RUMBLES. Rain falls harder. The DRIL SPINS down into the earth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinyl spinning on a record player. Something lofty, obscu

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: A record player? Am I paying for that? But you can tell the whole thing makes Wells happy. He’s whiskey. The native foreman is there. And through the fla two distant drills glow under colored tarpaulins.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: (re: the map) We're here. And now we step out ina semi-circular pattern. Six man crews, twelve hour shifts, around the clock. Tomorrow I'll start looking at core samples. We’ll send the most promising down river to the assay lab. When we get a hit we’ll drop holes to chart the contour of the vein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three foot ROCK CORES laid out in a wooden box... Pull ba reveal ten boxes... then twenty... Moving INSIDE --

dialogues.speaker: THE CORE SHED
dialogues.text: Where a CIRCULAR SAW cuts a CORE. Wells watching Acosta examine a section, then toss it in a ROCK CRUSHER... The RUBBLE is then bagged in canvas sacks... which are closed sealed with HOT WAX... and finally stamped with a WASHOE THE CORE SAMPLES are carried in a long line through the v toward the river -- an Indonesian Salgado come to life. Wells and Acosta watch, all hopes and dreams in that line  39.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What do we do now? CAMERA RISES UP from the workers carrying the core sample the limestone cliffs and endless sky.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We wait. And we keep drilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells sprays himself liberally in bug spray, making a clo under the light. Almost immediately a bug bites his shoul

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: These bugs don’t give a fuck about this bug spray.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CAMP STOVE
dialogues.text: Wells, spatula in hand, watches mystery meat sizzle. He c and talks over his shoulder to Acosta who is working. WELLS (CONT’D) The guy who invented the hamburger was smart. But the guy who invented the cheeseburger... Genius. He begins serving them up. WELLS (CONT’D) Don’t ask where this meat came from. IT’S LATER They're both relaxing. Wells maybe a bit more relaxed. WELLS (CONT’D) Goddamn jungle. Nothing for 200 miles and look at us. Not so bad. Acosta takes in the night. Raises his cup in a salute to dark jungle all around. They both drink.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: What’s the meaning of the tattoo?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: It’s from a poem I read as a kid: (Acosta waits) The bird with no feet sleeps on the wind.  39aA.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You're full of mysteries, Wells. You really are.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You got any tattoos, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Only on the inside. Wells looks at him a beat, then looks out into the dark. sounds of drilling drift across the valley floor.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: And a LONE MESSENGER running up the trail...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells meets him halfway, takes the ASSAY REPORT and tears open, reading. Even from a distance we can tell it’s bad A DRILL IS MOVED to a NEW POSITION. DRILL 2 IS MOVED. COR ARE CRUSHED and BAGGED. A CANOE LOADED WITH CORE SAMPLES motors away down the rising river. The rain is torrential MAIN TENT looks like it’s about to float away. Acosta mee Obb... Wells meeting him... Acosta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta and Wells, back to back, working. Acosta thinking geology, Wells looking at financials. Realize neither one looking at an unopened report on the table. Finally Acost tears it open, reads it. Passes it to Wells: INDO-KARTA LABORATORIES - ASSAY REPORT.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: ...-These things look worse every time we get one. Acosta stares steadily at his map, which shows an increas desperate spray of holes. WELLS (CONT’D) Thirty, 100 meter holes, Mike. Thirty. And what do we got? We got shit.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Remember what I told you about patience?  39aB.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Remember what I told you about money?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Yeah, it wasn’t a problem.  39A. Looks at the numbers. They don’t lie.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: It’s a problem now.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: I‘1l try something else. Move further up the seam. Drop 80 meter holes. Move faster.  40.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Do it. Wells suddenly shudders with a chill. Acosta looks at him WELLS (CONT’D) I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You don’t look so good.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: It’s ninety-eight degrees out and pissing rain. And all we're pulling up is dinosaur shit. How am I supposed to look? (beat) Jesus, I'm freezing. Wells starts to shake. Acosta puts a hand to Wells's head

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You're burning up.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I’m fine. (off Acosta’s concern) I said, I’m fine. Wells forces himself to stand. He moves to Acosta's maps. WELLS (CONT’D) All right, where do we go next? But Wells has to sit. Off Acosta's concerned look WE GO..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fucking rain. WORKERS, meager items held in plastic assemble in their tent. The FOREMAN speaks to his men.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O)
dialogues.text: We drilled our holes, assayed the cores and got nothing. Zero. We were nearly busted, out of money, out of time. Workers quitting. But, no way I was giving up, I was gonna find a way to keep going if it killed me.  41. One RIG IS SILENT. Wells struggles across the compound th the downpour to stop the men from leaving. He falls. Pick himself up. Waves his arms. Yells in a language they don’ speak. Even the buffalo is leaving. He slips again --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I picked up a bad case of malaria, which takes out something like a million people a year... And I was on the list. From the mud he sees the workers vanishing, a skeleton cr the remaining rig. He rolls on his back. And still the ra comes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta enters. Doesn’t realize Wells is slumped in a chai the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: The workers are leaving, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: I know. I’ve got the new assay reports. Acosta lights a lantern, sees Wells. ACOSTA (CONT’D) Jesus. Get your ass in bed already. It’s an effort for Wells to speak, painful.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to talk about. We’re not finding anything. Wells sags. The reality that he’s losing again sinking in Wells has another fit of chills. He’s half-delirious.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Maybe we’re pushing them too hard. Maybe we should take it easy, enjoy it a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Take it easy? Is that a Reno bumper sticker? The losers’ credo.  42.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Nah, man, it’s just life. Sometimes you just gotta take it easy... I’m freezing. Acosta helps him to his cot. Pulls the thin blanket over. WELLS (CONT’D) Maybe cut ‘em all in... offer ownership, share in the upside... The DISTANT WHINE of the last drill suddenly GOES QUIET. TIMELESS CACOPHONY of the jungle RISES. WELLS (CONT’D) I’m scared, Mike. Don’t let me die out here for nothing... Wells passes out into a feverish sleep. Acosta watches hi long time before reaching a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta steps into the empty, silent camp. Rain curtaining his hat. He sets out alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta walking through the rainy jungle toward a village. natives in the limestone cliffs looking down. Acosta pass pond where people bathe and fill jugs with muddy water. AT THE LONGHOUSE there are DAYAK WOMEN on the porch. Acos has a few quiet words. One slowly stands, disappears thro the DARK OPENING. Acosta cannot see inside. It’s too dark remaining women look at him evenly. The “FOREMAN” appears obviously a LOCAL CHIEF.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: (Dayak) What can I do to get you to return to work? We are running out of money, it’s true. But we’re close. I know it. A beat as the foreman considers Acosta. Then he gestures follow. The rising CRIES of a child can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thrumming rain on the thatch and in half-gloom find a fev CHILD. Acosta watches as the mother tries to get him to t sip of water. Acosta kneels and passes his canteen to the mother. Urges her to pour clean water.  43.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He realized what they needed wasn’t stock options, but drinking water and antibiotics. And damned if he didn’t go to every little place every one of our people came from. Streams that had no name. All feeding the great Kensana river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A skeptical Jennings observes Wells a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: And you believe this was sincere?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Mike’s half a native anyway. He was trying everything. And I was a mess. Malaria is no joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monsoon continues, but Wells is oblivious, a shudderi chill wracking his body. Acosta watches this uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: We need to get you out of here. I’m pulling the plug.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Not happening. Tell me the plan.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: What they need... they need clean water, antibiotics... (reluctant) If we get filter systems up here, I think they'll come back. Wells looks up with dim eyes, a smile crossing his face.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I’ve got maybe eighteen hundred dollars of room left on the Visa. Five hundred on Diner’s Club. Use it all. Wells hot and dry. Acosta looks down at him. He doesn’t t Wells is gonna make it. He’s seen it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A break in the rain. Misty clouds circle limestone mounta  43A. Brown water in a micro filter as Acosta hangs it from a branch. Clear water flows out a hose. A child tastes the water, doesn’t like it. Several children laugh. In the river a mother sits with her baby on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Acosta fills ANOTHER FILTER, reveal NATIVES finding go the stream. It almost mocks Acosta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SAME LIMESTONE CLIFFS... ONLY NOW WE TILT DOWN and FI

dialogues.speaker: NOISES MIXED WITH JUNGLE.
dialogues.text: Wells tossing and turning on the cot having his fever dre

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I spent the next few weeks in a malarial haze. I should have been dead. The workers stayed. Mike kept it all going. And he kept me alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta in the rain, turns and sees something that stops h

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did he manage to enjoy himself a little bit along the way..? A BEAUTIFUL NATIVE GIRL stares at Acosta through the rain It’s like they know each other. WELLS (V.O. How should I know? I was delirious. I do not recommend Malaria treated with a bunch of leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain. And the sound of an IGNITING FLAME... FUMMM --! A B FLAME. And Wells in and out of consciousness to find a BO in their tent brewing a potion of herbs as Acosta watches

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: No idea. But they say it works.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: They don’t have electricity. Or socks. The Boretn brings a bamboo mug toward Wells.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Come on, get it down.  45. Wells chokes down the remedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Limestone cliffs and mist. Drills spinning, biting into e Clouds passing overhead. Men feeding pipe to the machine. Wells drenched in sweat, looking like death -- ACOSTA and FOREMAN load CORE SAMPLES onto a boat. DRILLS SPINNING, biting into the earth/WELLS TOSSING, TUR drenched as the FEVER FINALLY BREAKS. Obb brings another report. Acosta reads, betraying no emo FEVER DREAM: A RAFT FLOATING ON A GOLDEN RIVER... We’re drifting toward it as it goes around a bend... SOMETHING it... a BODY.. FUNERAL BIER. Closer... closer... it’s WEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WELLS COMES TO -- surprised to be alive. Surprised it’s n raining. Realizes Acosta is right there looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What day is it?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: No idea.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Month?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: August. See this is a different month than Wells expected.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You been sitting here this whole time?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Let’s not get carried away. Wells now realizes Acosta has an assay report.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You gonna talk, or what?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: We pulled seventeen more cores. He looks at Wells, unreadable.  45A.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What? What do they say? No good?  46.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Not good... Wells falls back. Acosta stands, a completely different l on his face, one of wonder -- ACOSTA (CONT’D) More in the vicinity of great. Wells looks up. A face that’s almost afraid to hope.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Don’t mess around, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Eighth of an ounce per ton. Wells scans the reports, rising to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Eighth of an ounce per... WHAT!!?? Acosta smiles -- Wells is in shock.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: We've got a strike, Kenny. Wells smiles, laughs, screams!

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: We've got ourselves a gold mine!

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: That we do. Wells struggles up to his feet and joins Acosta best he c jumping up and down.

dialogues.speaker: MINE..
dialogues.text: CAMERA DRIFTS outside to meet Wells who appears through t doorway as he YELLS TO THE HILLS --

dialogues.speaker: WE GOT A GODDAMN GOLD MINE --
dialogues.text: Which ECHOES back to him from the cliffs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POP!!! Gold-leafed bottles in buckets. Champagne sprays f the bottle as Wells moves through the crowd at the bar, filling everyone's glasses.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O)
dialogues.text: That moment, there’s no way I could possibly describe the feeling. The regulars are all here, sharing in Wells's victory.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O)
dialogues.text: It’s amazing how a little gold dust can change everything. For better or worse, the ride had begun. And what a goddamn ride...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is vibrating! MUSIC OVER. Wells is with Bobby B and Connie and Nevins celebrating at the bar. Kay passing a round of drinks, the last one to Wells. Kenny looks at Kay; Kay looks at Kenny, deep into each ot a small moment of private understanding in passing that s it all. Then he turns to his guys:

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: To the best team in the business!

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You're a stand up guy, Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: NEVINS
dialogues.text: To sharing the wealth.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: To the mother lode! They clink glasses and drink deeply, "To the mother lode!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and Kay driving into the hills on a perfect afterno Fun and carefree, windows down, 70’s music on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Smell that? Smell that air? Mountain air. It’s a tonic.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Ah, so good. So good.  47A. They're singing along. Passing small family ranches.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember I told you Janice got promoted to run Truckee?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. Good for her.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Well, Carl asked me if I’d like to be considered to take her place. Assistant Manager position. Outside the car as they go zipping past, music trailing, GHOST TOWN, faded signs and abandoned buildings... A dang sign reads, “MAGGIE'S CREEK... Pop -- “0” in spray paint.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: That’s great, babe.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Everything's working out so great.  48. By way of agreement he rubs her thigh where the dress has ridden up. Sunlight filters through the trees above. Kay’ toes are painted eggshell blue.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You’re gonna be able to quit all of it if you want... Never work another day in your life. Blue skies coming.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. Wells drives down a country lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells stops, gets out and starts around the car.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (happy) Kenny Wells, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Eyes closed. No peeking. He opens Kay’s door, leads her a short distance. WELLS (CONT’D) Okay, now open ‘em. She opens her eyes. In her eyes something immense that mu comprehended. And for a moment we don’t see what she’s se and then we do:

dialogues.speaker: DREAM RANCH LAND
dialogues.text: The sweep of ranch land is epic. Prairie dogs hop away. E the distance the size of ants.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: It’s going to be our place, above it all, away from it all. Like we always wanted. We’ll put the house here. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fieldstone and oak. The kind that lasts forever. A big kitchen where I’m standing. And a great room with two fireplaces. He turns to look at Kay, to see if she’s going with it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Can we afford this?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Almost, baby. Almost... Wells jogs a short distance away, still going...

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bedrooms here and here and here... And here... For the kids. Ah, come on, Kay... How many kids?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: People usually start with one. They look at each other. It’s golden hour. Then she skips through the field toward him.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kitchen should go the other way, Kenny. To get the morning light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells laying it out for the boys: Burns, Connie, and Nevi

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: It’ll be straight commission to start, but this hook’s got meat on it. There’s money out there, so reel it in. They throw back the rest of what’s in their glasses. Well leans over and whispers to Bobby Burns. WELLS (CONT’D) This stock’s gonna start cooking. You sell a little here and there. Don’t wait. Think rainy day, Bobby boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car doors are open, a great SONG plays on the radio. and Kay slow dance in the field as a glorious sunset fade  50. And PULLING BACK to find a BILLBOARD ON STILTS showing a “dream house.” As Kay and Wells slowly turn in the distan and the music is gently blown away across the fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells and Kay dancing in that way happy couples do, almos like they’re one person, her head melting against his che

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kenny... this is Walt Kealer. He publishes “The Gold Digger.”

dialogues.speaker: KEALER
dialogues.text: We reach a half a million readers and they’d all love to know what you got cooking over there in Indonesia. You have a minute, I’1l buy you a drink. Kealer, a serious guy, and Burns both look at Kay.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) No one dances like you. (to the world) He’s all yours, Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Hell, I read the Gold Digger. Step over to my office, Walt. Wells signals for two drinks, leads Kealer to the booth.

dialogues.speaker: KEALER
dialogues.text: They're saying you bring this in, you'll get the Golden Pickaxe. What do you say about that?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I say we probably just jinxed it.

dialogues.speaker: KEALER
dialogues.text: How many ounces you guessing?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Millions of ounces, Walt. Millions. Kealer whistles. Makes a note.  50A.

dialogues.speaker: KEALER
dialogues.text: Placer mining?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Hard rock. It ain’t amateur hour.

dialogues.speaker: KEALER
dialogues.text: How's the infrastructure?  51.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Building it from the ground up. Wells sees Kay at the bar flirting/teasing with two regul Queen of the runway. He loves this.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Kay waits for Roy to mix fresh drinks.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (nodding at Wells) Seems like someone’s ship is finally coming in.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Everyone's, Roy. (so proud) He makes shit happen. He really does. A customer sidles up and wraps a big arm around. Kay flas some wattage --

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: JD, where you been hidin’ yourself? BACK WITH WELLS --—

dialogues.speaker: KEALER
dialogues.text: On a different tack, what do you think your dad would say if he could see you right now?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: The last card you turn over is the one that matters. INT. COLEMAN & MEAD CAPITAL GROUP - CLIVE’S OFFICE - DAY CLIVE Coleman, 70's, flanked by a now-deferential Andrews Stanton, opposite Wells.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Kenny, your father and I started out together in this business. Hell, he put me in the business, but I don’t have to tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Dad always spoke well of you, Clive.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: One of the best men I ever knew.  5laA. The mention of his father in this context makes Wells pro

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've gone from 4 to 23 cents on the first assay result. And you've pulled two more that confirmed those findings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three more.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Three more... I'd like to underwrite a private placement of Washoe stock. I believe we can raise between eight and ten million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Capital’s definitely top of the agenda right now.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: A lot of folks will want to make this deal, but we’ve got history and I hope you know you can trust me. I only wish you'd brought it to me sooner. I could have helped you from the get-go. 51a.  52. Wells’ gaze now slides to Stanton, a deer in headlights. pushes his coffee mug across the table.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Top that off for me, will you? Stanton rises and exits with Wells’s mug. WE FOLLOW HIM -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanton walks to the kitchenette. A COWORKER looks at him a condemned man. Hear LAUGHTER from the conference room. pours the coffee, takes a deep breath, and heads back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanton comes back in to find the group on their feet, We shaking hands with Clive Coleman.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Stanton. Mr. Wells has agreed to give us his business. On one condition. Stanton blanches. Here it comes. Wells is stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I want you to personally handle my account. I need you to be available to me 24-7 and 365. Stanton is speechless for just a moment, but finds his vo

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Yes. Thank you. Clive slaps the stunned Stanton on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Seems you made quite an impression. A look between Wells and Stanton, a look of understanding Stanton is grateful, but also knows that Wells owns him.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be a wild-ass ride. You ready for that?  53.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Then what are we standing here for? Let’s go make some money.

dialogues.text: -- THE WASHOE SITE -- the noise is staggering as ACOSTA supervises more core drilling. FOUR DRILLS now working, CONVERGING as they MAP THE CONTOURS of the vein. -- THE ASSAY LAB -- a Washoe sack is cut open, the crushe rock core sample is poured onto an industrial scale. -- THE THREE GREENHORNS BAR -- Wells, Bobby Burns and the work the phones. Kay brings Wells another Seagrams. He gi her a smile, never missing a beat of his pitch. -- STOCK TICKER -- Washoe climbs...$2.75...$3.10...$4.87.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Kenny. You check the last report?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m looking at it now... Holy shit...

dialogues.speaker: HOLY SHIT
dialogues.text: -- VIEW THROUGH A MICROSCOPE -- and there it is, scattere among the base rock -- GOLD! Flecks of it, but there’s something preternatural about the way it glitters, and at magnification, it is mesmerizing.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Holy shit is right, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Whoooow!!!

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Damn nice of Roy to loan us that Elk. She pushes him backwards by his chest until he’s sitting desk chair. She straddles him. Corner windows. View of Re WELLS (CONT’D) Kay, do you want to work here? Quit all those other jobs? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You be the prospector, Mr. Wells. I’11 be the barmaid who got swept off her feet. He spins his chair. Around and around they go --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I love you, Kay.

dialogues.text: You better.

dialogues.speaker: INDONESIAN MINE
dialogues.text: OUNCES!" Connie stares in disbelief.

dialogues.text: We’re gonna be so fucking rich.

dialogues.text: -- A COMPUTER SCREEN -- WASHOE’S FINANCIALS displayed in GRAPHS and CHARTS. WASHOE’S SHARE PRICE is listed at $6.2 Pull back to reveal WE ARE in --

dialogues.text: A young banker, BRIAN WOOLF (30's), scans the info on his screen. He hits print and strides across the trading floo He barely breaks stride as he passes the PRINTER, grabbin freshly printed documents and we go... INT. BROWN, THOMAS - HOLLIS DRESHER’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LA 50th Floor. Breathtaking Manhattan views. We are suddenly long, long way from Reno. A file on a desk: IDEAS FOR HOL  55.

dialogues.speaker: CONVICTION
dialogues.text: Woolf stands before HOLLIS DRESHER (50's), impeccable in bespoke, as Dresher looks over the newly printed document

dialogues.speaker: DRESHER
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: Wildcatters basically. This Acosta had some success before. Copper. Got taken over by Freeport Mac. It’s all in there. Dresher takes a moment before looking up from the documen

dialogues.speaker: DRESHER
dialogues.text: I like this. Bring them in. Let’s have a closer look. INT. WASHOE OFFICES - “CONFERENCE ROOM” - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A folding table in Kenny’s office. Wells is with Bobby Bu Connie Wright and Stanton... a Washoe board meeting.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: We're about fifty percent allocated right now. And we want to set aside thirty of the remaining fifty for you boys to unload. They love this idea. It’s low-hanging fruit at this point

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Hold that thought. I gotta bleed the beast. As soon as he’s gone, the phone RINGS. They all stare at

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY /CONNIE/NEVINS
dialogues.text: Kay!! Through the doorway, passing, without missing a beat --

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Good morning, Washoe Mining. How may I direct your call. (beat) Please hold. She covers the mouthpiece, then realizes they actually ha hold button. Which she presses.  56.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kenny! You got a call! Wells emerges from the executive head. They all watch him up the receiver. Press the button.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: This is Kenny Wells. INT. BROWN, THOMAS - DRESHER’S OFFICE - NEW YORK - DAY Woolf, looking over the skyline.

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: Mr. Wells. This is Bryan Woolf of Brown, Thomas, in New York.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells is listening, starting to fidget nervously.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Wait. Really? ... (covering phone) Bryan Woolf, mineral group at Brown, Thomas in NYC.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: (impressed) Brown, Thomas. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay. Okay... I look forward to it. Wells slowly hangs up. Everyone looking, what just happen Then, Wells calling out -- WELLS (CONT’D) Kay, they’re flying me out! Everyone feeling a bit of awe and excitement. Kay’s smile painted there like a barmaid Mona Lisa.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Seagrams building, solid as the booze that built it. at the base, Wells staring up. As Acosta looks him over.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Wells. Wells--!

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I truly had no idea there was a Seagrams building. Like the Vatican.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Wells! Where’d you get the tie? Wells looks down at the tie.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Airport. Forty bucks. Don’t like it? Acosta snaps off the tag still hanging from the loop.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Who you talking to, Mikey? But Wells’s eye is caught by some WALL STREET HONCHOS, composed, confident, effortless, heading to a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Wells!

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Stop saying my name. Are you ready? Wells pulls his gaze back. They look at each other. Neith one is ready. WELLS (CONT’D) Shit. We’re all just selling used cars. Wells brushes by confidently. AND WE GO:  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woolf, Dresher and others in THE MINERAL GROUP. In this rarefied air, Wells looks out of his depth --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: We've got a private placement in play right now that’s over fifty percent subscribed! And that’s off our current assays. The numbers keep coming in good, and they will, sky’s the limit on this thing. Woolf steps up, he’s sophisticated, confident.

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: You don’t need to sell us, Mr. Wells. We’ve done the math and we believe you're sitting on the largest gold find of the decade. At Brown, Thomas we have a history of helping guide people such as yourself through what are sometimes complicated waters.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Complicated how?

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: That delicate balance, Mr. Wells, between being asset rich and cash poor. The important thing is we believe you can go all the way and we want to help you get there. Wells loves this. Woolf has said exactly the right thing, you also get the feeling he has done this many times befo WOOLF (CONT’D) We'll need big money onboard, of course, investment banks, mutual fund managers, pension fund administrators. We have the team and the relationships to introduce you to this world.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: We've done all right up to now.

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: There is no doubt about that. He smiles.  59. WOOLF (CONT’D) May I speak plainly, Mr. Wells? Wells looks at Acosta, then back to Woolf.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: That’s the only way to speak, Bryan.

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: Our clients will want to see a serious plan to turn lab results in a volatile region into an investment we can all stake our reputations on.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: That’s not gonna be a problem --

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: It’s not a problem, per se, but there remains the fact that neither of you have taken a find of this magnitude all the way through production.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. We found it. We can dig it up. It’s not that complicated.

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: (choosing words carefully) Actually, historically, what we've found is it can be quite complicated and we'd like to help formulate how you present the operations side. Suddenly Wells is beginning to feel a little pushed.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What does that even mean? What’s he saying?

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: I'd like you both to consider bringing on a strategic partner. Wells is suddenly wary. And we see how small town he real is. He lifts Woolf's business card --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (reads ) Managing Director of Substrate Minerals, Metals, Oil, and Gas. I don’t even know what that is. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have any of you ever set one of your hand-made loafers down in a hole on the side of a mountain? Washoe has history. 59A.  60.

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: We've done a fairly thorough analysis of Washoe, Mr. Wells. And we believe you need some strategic help.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: It’s a new day. And Indo is goddamn different. (bangs table) I know how to bring this baby in! Acosta observes Wells for a moment. We think Acosta is go to judge him, pile on... instead:  61.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Wells came and found me. I was at a low point, I’1l admit. It happens in this business. Ups and downs. He backed me with his last cent. More than that he risked his life. Almost lost it, too. And now we have the bull by its horns.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: A big-ass bull!

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: I’ve worked with the best and I can tell you Kenny Wells is up there with them. Which must count for something. A declaration of friendship, and faith. This means the wo

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: It does, Mr. Acosta. We’re not by any stretch of the imagination suggesting that anyone take a backseat, we're simply asking you to be open to strategic alliances.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: No fucking way. That’s that. Acosta goes to the window. He looks out.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: There’s something about finding gold -- it's difficult to put into words -- the taste of it on your tongue, gritty and electric, the feel of it between your fingers. It’s like a drug. It hooks you. It’s what you’re missing here in the city; so you must understand why we feel a bit possessive over it. (beat) So I have proposal: put together your institutional players, the guys who rep the big money, whomever needs to kick the tires on this thing... And we'll take them on a little trip up the river... Now Wells is looking at Acosta, starting to go with it -- ACOSTA (CONT’D) You know what river that is?  61A.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: The only river that matters -- the

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: And they can decide for themselves if we're ready to scale this thing up.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: So it was Acosta who proposed the junket to Kensana? Or did you cook that up together? Wells looking at Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You just don’t get it. We weren’t “cooking up” anything. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was getting hit from all sides by people wanting in -- Hart Hubbard, my neighbor, lawn care professional, usually worried about Kay’s mulberry over his back fence, only now he’s dropping mining terms, “Kenny, I hear the grade purity at Kensana is quite high. How is the core frequency?” Hart Hubbard. He cuts grass for a living.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: We've interviewed Mr. Hubbard. Wells looks at Jennings and Banks and Levine. All dressed in their middle-class rectitude.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I’m just saying I wasn’t feeling like I had to cook up anything.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: So it was Acosta who proposed the banker junket?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes. (can’t help himself) And it was a genius move. I don’t exactly cut the right figure in a Wall Street boardroom. They didn’t like my suit or the smell of my whiskey. And let's be clear: we were in a fight, a fight for control. With that one move Mike shifted the balance of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of BANKERS blinking in blinding tropical sunlight they follow Wells out of the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They were coming to our house and that was a whole new ball game. OWENS (40), BINKERT and JACKSON (30’s). These are men set from the concrete jungle, ready for a taste of the real t They all pull wheeled carry-ons, some dressed in the late “in” safari-wear from Ralph Lauren. They’re met by Mike Acosta, in full bush gear. Suddenly t Bankers’ outfits look foolishly ersatz.  63.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is Mike Acosta.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Anyone who wants to turn back, this is your last chance. They all look at him, “Is he fucking kidding?..."

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: He’s messin’ with you, come on. A few of the Bankers sigh, some aren’t sure. WELLS (CONT’D) Welcome to Indo, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front of a canoe breaks the plane, followed by Owens, Binkert, Jackson... taking it all in. It’s one of those perfect tropical days -- a balmy breeze, glorious sunshin billowing clouds hanging in an impossibly blue sky. They pass TRIBESMEN panning along the bank.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: They’ve been panning this river for five thousand years. That’s how it got its name... Kensana. It means -- He shoots a look to Acosta, making the Bankers wait for i

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: River of gold.

dialogues.speaker: OWENS
dialogues.text: That’s not real? A smile between Wells and Acosta -- this is the show and they’re loving it. And RISING UP the river is indeed gold colored, snaking through hills of green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A BULLDOZER CLEARS A SECTION OF JUNGLE -- a CREW works DRILL RIG. Acosta shouts over the din, machete in his han

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: When we got the hit, we stepped out in a radiating pattern...We’ll keep going until we have the complete picture of (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the underlying geology-- how long, how wide, how deep. It’s this mapping that gives us the real sense of what we’re sitting on. The men look down at the ground. It’s just ground. But th imaginations are working. Acosta points all around them. ACOSTA (CONT’D) It’s everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta leads the group into the CORE SHED. Throughout the building, lying in wooden cradles, are the CORE SAMPLES - foot long cylinders of rock and earth.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Our typical drill depth is between three and five hundred feet. We pull out our core samples in six foot segments, six inches in diameter packed solid with rock and soil. He moves to a massive workbench covered with crushed rock ACOSTA (CONT’D) This building is guarded 24/7 and kept under lock and key. Acosta pulls the leather thong around his neck from his s see a huge GOLD NUGGET and a key -- ACOSTA (CONT’D) This is the key. With that, he hoists up a diamond blade CIRCULAR SAW and hums to life. He brings the blade down on the rock, OBLITERATING the rock, and our hearing, as it cuts a thre foot section of core. Again, he shouts over the noise -- ACOSTA (CONT’D) The cores are cut into sections and then crushed! He heaves the cut section into a CRUSHER which AUTOMATICA ACTIVATES the mechanism -- adding insult to aural injury. ACOSTA (CONT’D) The pulverized cores are then bagged and sealed!  65. He produces a WAX-SEALED CANVAS SACK as an example. Start heave it toward the bankers who dance out of the way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SAME SACK lands on a freighter canoe with other sacks labeled and sealed, and under GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Under guard, the samples are sent down river to independent labs in Kalimantan. If a seal is broken or damaged in any way, the lab, by law, has to discard the entire sample. (beat) The bottom line is every safeguard has been put in place to assure the security of the process. The Bankers nod, impressed. But that’s not really what th came all this way for. They’re not quite sold.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Diamond tipped saw blades, rock crushers and core samples ripped from the guts of the earth... It all sounds great, but that’s not what you came to see. Am I wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: No, you’re not. Wells and Acosta exchange a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You boys want to see some gold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late afternoon sun filters through the canopy. This could Eden. A few of the bankers, knee deep, pan the rocky bott

dialogues.speaker: BINKERT
dialogues.text: No one’s gonna believe this shit. Owens swats at a bug. He looks more annoyed than impresse

dialogues.speaker: OWENS
dialogues.text: So, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: BINKERT
dialogues.text: Not sure. What about you?  66.

dialogues.speaker: OWENS
dialogues.text: Acosta seems to know what he’s talking about but, I don’t know... Jackson, working the river a few yards away, calls out!

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Hey, come here - check it out! Acosta heads out to him. Wells gestures to the pan.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Looks like it might be the stuff. Acosta holds the pan of mud up to the light -- glimmers o gold are seen in the fading sun. WELLS (CONT’D) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. The Bankers all watch, rapt -- Acosta takes the pan and m back to the river bank, dumps the mud into a waiting SLUR He takes a bucket of river water and starts pouring the w SLOWLY over the mud. Then, right before their very eyes.. ACOSTA (CONT’D) Keep your eyes peeled... Like magic... A HUGE GOLD NUGGET appears! Acosta holds it up into the l reveling in its sparkling quality. ACOSTA (CONT’D) (tosses it to Jackson) A few more like that and you can pave Wall Street. The Bankers are fucking speechless. Wells looks at the converted Owens...

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pay dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennings, jacket off, sleeves rolled up, paces. Wells rat the ice cubes in his empty glass.  67.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Now, I honestly don’t know if that was just a stroke of luck or an amazing piece of showmanship or both. But when Jackson pulled that nugget out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INDONESIAN GIRLS dance, somehow more naked than naked. It Wells, Acosta and the Bankers -- everyone getting loaded.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O)
dialogues.text: ...We had ‘em. Acosta shouts out to the BARTENDER in Bahasa. MUSIC UP. G dancing together. Acosta passing drinks to the bankers...

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: It’s called a convex dome. What every geologist dreams of finding and that’s what I think we've got at Kensana. Basically, it’s a volcano that’s collapsed in on itself, forming an inverted shell... Wells cups his hands.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: .»-.or a bowl full of all the stuff we're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: BINKERT
dialogues.text: How much “stuff” you think we're talking about? Acosta smiles, throws back his drink and shouts out to a waitress, holding up his empty glass, signalling for drin

dialogues.text: Our current assays point to a deposit of anywhere from ten to thirty-five million ounces. When we find the dome, and we will find it, I wouldn’t be surprised if we prove eighty to one hundred million ounces... Jackson still has the presence of mind to do some calcula on his calculator. dialogues.text: .--Is that right?  68-69. He redoes the calculations. They all wait. He looks again

dialogues.text: You're talking over thirty billion dollars. They all freeze. This is bigger than anyone imagined. Eve Wells suddenly has the queasy look of a man starting to l at the drop on a roller coaster. He raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: May we all be in heaven an hour before the IRS knows we’re dead. They laugh and, right on cue, out come the girls. Two for Banker. As one of the girls runs her fingers through Jackson's hair, her breasts pressing against his face, he turns to Owens...

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: The business trips are going to be outstanding.

dialogues.speaker: OWENS
dialogues.text: Hell of a write-off. Wells and Acosta stand off together, watching as the magi takes hold --

dialogues.text: Not a bad day. Acosta smiles. And as the party rages, WE GO:

dialogues.text: Hello?  70.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What are you doing, baby? It’s me. From halfway around the world.

dialogues.text: Kenny! (to someone OS) It’s Kenny -- (to Wells) I was just telling some people the story of how we met. dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Not-So-Amazing Cecil --

dialogues.text: Cec had this one trick, his only trick. Kenny came... (to Wells) How many shows in a row, Kenny --? Wells looks inside the suite where a last dancer sways in front of Acosta. The bankers have gone to bed.

dialogues.text: Twenty --

dialogues.text: Twenty shows in a row. And the trick was?

dialogues.text: Kay on a white phone in the La-Z-Boy area. A few coworker chuckling, heading back to their respective areas.

dialogues.text: How’s it going over there?  71.

dialogues.text: Wait. Kenny... Really? Really really? Wells looks at the lights, which seem to dance with desti

dialogues.text: I’m sending a plane for you, baby. A chariot like you deserve -- private jet -- to meet me in New York City... Blue skies... (off her pause) Did you hear me? Kay? Kay holding the phone... Sees a MANAGER, CARL, signalling

dialogues.text: I did... She suddenly just turns away and JUMPS FOR JOY -- WIDE IN THE STORE: Kay airborne --! Screaming with happin

dialogues.text: ...Brown, Thomas, in association with Coleman and Mead Capital Group, are proud to announce the initial public offering of Class-A common stock...

dialogues.speaker: WOOLF
dialogues.text: And the listing of Washoe Mining on the New York Stock Exchange! He holds the paper up with a smile. The boardroom ERUPTS!

dialogues.text: Kenny? Yellow roses lead the way, the main room of the suite fil with hundreds.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Through thick and fuckin’ thin... Thick ain’t so bad, Kenny Wells. He takes her in his arms, rolling across the huge bed.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are these the softest sheets you ever felt?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Let’s get under ‘em. And we begin to HEAR SHOUTING, a CRAZY ENERGY, WHICH TAKE  73.

dialogues.text: Wells and Kay exit the elevator and see Acosta waiting.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: My two favorite people in the world. Kay, Mike. Mike, Kay.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (re: Wells) You know this one stole my watch to go meet you?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
