And now we see a changed Wells. He looks good. Catches himself in the mirr Acosta catches the same reflection. Wells pulls cards from his jacket. Looks at Acosta. A tru friend is the one you feel comfortable practicing this ki speech in front of.  109. WELLS (CONT’D) My great granddad came out here on a wagon. He had a horse and two mules... (to Acosta) Too much?

dialogues.speaker: ACOSTA
dialogues.text: No, man. It’s good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountains in the distance. INT. HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - BALLROOM - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells at his table with Acosta, Bobby Burns, Stanton, Cli Connie, Nevins. He’s quiet. This means a lot him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY BURNS
dialogues.text: Kenny, you’re a star, boy. Don’t sweat it. I mean really, don’t sweat. He’s sweating. Someone passes him a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: MC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s been a long night and I’m sure you will soon hit the tables here at Harrah's Reno and make it a lot longer night. And hit those tables people... it’s why Verna makes the rooms so reasonable. Laughter around the room. A few big firms have tables. An lots of smaller players. It’s everyone’s night.

dialogues.speaker: MC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They do accept gold for bar tabs... (laughter) Now we come to our last honor, the 1988 Golden Pickaxe for “Prospector Of The Year,” which goes to our own Kenny Wells! Get up here, Kenny--! Wells rises and makes his way, showered with applause and FLASHING cameras. The crowd rises, saluting Wells, saluti that part of themselves that hangs on, refuses to give up Wells cradles the Golden Pickaxe statue, which is exactly it sounds, a golden pickaxe. He stares out, savoring his moment. Then holds it up as flashbulbs flash. Pulls his speech from his pocket. Looks out at faces, lau faces, no one taking this quite so seriously.  110.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Every last one of us who calls the great state of Nevada home arrived here with a dream.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yelling out) Drinks on Kenny. Laughter. And AT WELLS'S TABLE --

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: Great state of Nevada? He sees Kay. He smiles. Realizes it’s not her.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: ...That was my great granddad who came out here on a wagon. Had a horse and two mules when they finally stopped moving and said this was the place, he was only about forty miles from right here. At the back of the room, ACOSTA IS LEAVING. He pauses and turns to Wells. A nod of respect and congratulations pass unspoken between them. And then ACOSTA IS GONE. Wells looks at the statue. WELLS (CONT’D) What is a prospector? (the crowd groans) No, I’m serious. It’s someone who believes it’s out there. Who wakes up every morning and somehow believes. Again and again. It’s not there. Standing at the edge of a desert, watching the sun rise and something in him says, “it’s that way, just walk.” FLASH, FLASH, FLASH! Wells walks the center aisle, drowne flashing light and glorious adoration. Everyone’s reachin to shake his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And the sun is higher and it’s getting hot and nobody else sees anything. And everyone else wants to turn back... And then IT’S LATER and EVERYONE’S CROWDED AT THE BAR. Champagne corks are popping. POP POP POP.  111. WELLS (V.O.) (CONT’D) And everyone else has turned back. And now he’s alone. And it’s burning hot. And there is no water... And ON THE CASINO FLOOR Wells is PLAYING ROULETTE. The WH IS SPINNING. STACKS OF MONEY are moving. SHOW GIRLS ARE FLOCKING. Then IT’S EVEN LATER. WELLS IS SPORTING DRINKS ALL AROUND Champagne. POP POP POP.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s out there... It’s out there... It’s out there... TIGHTER ON THE FACE OF KENNY WELLS as he sits back at his table, accepting the congratulations of his friends. As p call his name and cheer and FLASHBULBS POP -- POP POP POP BACK AT THE PODIUM. Tight on Wells as he takes in all of listening faces. WELLS (CONT’D) And it doesn’t matter whether he finds it or not. It doesn’t matter. That’s a prospector. He basks in it, the words vibrating for everyone in the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracking across the detritus of a huge night to find Well bed, sound asleep. The phone starts to RING -- Wells does move. Then finally he moans, rolls toward the phone --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Hello..? What..? What? Wells is instantly awake. Hear the INDONESIAN FOREMAN say something FRANTIC over the and over-- WELLS (CONT’D) I’m sorry I can’t understand you. No go? I don’t understand. Slowly. Speak more slowly.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (slowly) No gold. There is NO GOLD. The window behind Wells reveals sun just catching the pea flaming morning gold. Wells grips the phone like a lifeli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mob scene outside. As Wells pulls up in his car, the cr converges on him. He can barely get his car door open. He squeezes out and pushes through the furious crowd --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I don’t know any more than you do right now! ...-But nobody’s hearing him -- PEOPLE shout out: “You fu thief!" “I'm gonna kill you!" “Where's our money?!" WELLS (CONT’D) I will get to the bottom of this! I promise! Suddenly, out of nowhere -- A FIST -- WHAM -- right acros Wells's face! It staggers him. The crowd lets out a roar approval. This is getting real ugly, real fast. A PAIR OF HANDS GRABS WELLS. He turns, panic in his eyes but it’s Connie Wright. Bobby Burns is with him. They pul Wells through the mob to the building’s side entrance.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Total shit storm, Kenny. Wells is still dazed.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I know... I know... They fight the last few feet to the door and as they forc their way inside, WE FOLLOW THEM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re out of breath, adrenaline pumping. Wells turns to face his friends’ haunted expressions...

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What happened? How did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: The independent assayer... they couldn’t reproduce Mike’s findings.  113. Wells trying to take it in.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: There’s no gold, Kenny. There’s no goddamn gold. There never was.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: That’s not possible.

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE OF SCENES --
dialogues.text: CNN NEWS CENTER -- A professorial looking MINING EXPERT explains to a NEWS ANCHOR...

dialogues.speaker: MINING EXPERT
dialogues.text: It’s called “salting” and it literally means, when someone sprinkles gold dust into a sample of rock, like you'd add salt to a steak. GOLD DUST -- pours onto a DIGITAL SCALE. MINING EXPERT (CONT’D) By all appearances, Washoe’s security protocols were iron-clad. But if the person administering security is fraudulent, the system breaks down. Then, the gold dust sprinkles into a GROUND SAMPLE OF ROC MINING EXPERT (CONT’D) ...It’s the oldest trick in the book.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: “Oldest trick in the book.” And yet major mining corporations, investment banks, auditors, everyone was fooled.

dialogues.speaker: MINING EXPERT
dialogues.text: We weren’t fooled; we didn’t look. TIGHT ON: A MAGNIFIED IMAGE -- TWO GOLD SAMPLES, side by side. The one on the LEFT has smoothly rounded edges; the on the RIGHT is angular and jagged.

dialogues.speaker: GEOLOGIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The image on the left is the type of gold found in the Washoe samples. This is river gold - notice how the edges are rounded, worn smooth by the erosion of the water. WE PULL BACK to --  114. A FINANCIAL SHOW -- The GEOLOGIST is seated across from a Cramer-type financial HOST. GEOLOGIST (CONT’D) ...What we should have found is flake gold - the sample on the right, pulled directly from the rock, rough edged and angular. The Host is nearly apoplectic --

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: That seems like a pretty big freakin’ detail to overlook!

dialogues.speaker: GEOLOGIST
dialogues.text: It’s a big detail. But you have to understand, everything else about the Washoe samples was right...

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: ..-But the gold was wrong! It’s right there, that’s what you’re saying?!

dialogues.speaker: GEOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are hard at work, going over financial documents Wells is on a phone at the center of it all --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Acosta? Mike Acosta? No. Yes, I do mind waiting -- Did he or did he not come to the Kalimantan? Bobby Burns approaches Wells. Burns looks gut-punched.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: The New York Stock Exchange just suspended trading. They’re taking Washoe off the board. Washoe is done, finished. Wells sinks back in his chair. slowly hangs up the phone. The news seems to take whateve he’s got left out of him. A long silent moment. There’s nothing more to say, but Bu just stands there. He looks in shock, like he’s had his s ripped out. Wells looks up at him...  115.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You sold some, right? Put something away? Burns hesitates before answering...

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: Yeah... Of course. You? Wells nods halfheartedly. It’s clear neither sold a damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Bobby?... Burns can’t meet Wells's eyes. WELLS (CONT’D) Goddammit, Bobby! I told you to sell some.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: I thought...I thought... it was just going to keep going up. Wells is genuinely distressed. And then Burns looks up -- eyes are damp, on the verge of crying. He can barely spea

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kenny, did you know, Did you know, Kenny? It’s like a blow to the heart.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What? Did I know? I can’t believe you would ask me that. Burns looks absolutely crushed. WELLS (CONT’D) I’ll take care of you, Bobby. Connie rushes in carrying a sheath of PAPERS.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Kenny... Burns’ expression hardens -- fists clenched like he’s gon punch Wells.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to take care of me! I want you to leave me the hell alone!  116. Burns walks away, a busted man. Wells turns to Connie. On look and he knows this is big.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I don’t even know how to say this -- He dumps the papers on Wells's desk.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. Wells reads. It doesn’t take him long to understand. He t a glass at the wall. It shatters.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: Connie answers Stanton’s questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Acosta was dumping stock. Shell companies. Banks in the Philippines, the Azores. Multiple layers. All off- shore.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Get ready for it... 164 million.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! What do we do? Kenny?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: There’s gotta be an explanation. We gotta find Mike! AT THAT MOMENT, they hear TIRES SCREECHING, CAR DOORS SLAMMING. And look outside. DOZENS OF AGENTS rolling up, familiar blue jackets with the white lettering -- FBI. He them entering. Then, a BULLHORN:

dialogues.speaker: FBI
dialogues.text: This is the FBI! Step away from your desks! Take two big steps away from your desks. Do not touch anything!  117. MONTAGE of FBI raid. Floor by floor. They arrive at Wells office. Connie and Stanton in the middle of the room, fro Wells at the window. Below, he sees the SPECIAL AGENT IN CHARGE step out of a car, already giving quiet orders -- It’s JENNINGS. Who looks up. Sees Wells at the window. Wells looks at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting with ROGER MUDD is MARK HANCOCK, chairman of Newp Holdings. Hancock as clean as snow as he rewrites history

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: We suspected there were problems early on, which is why we decided not to pursue the joint venture Washoe offered us. We got as many of our investors out of Washoe as fast as possible. An insert PHOTO of Kenny Wells and Mike Acosta appears.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER MUDD
dialogues.text: You made a lot of money. I mean before the walls came tumbling down. Hancock doesn't want to talk about that. ROGER MUDD (CONT’D) And how much money was lost in the fraud? That we know of.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Billions. Large institutional investors lost billions of dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER MUDD
dialogues.text: So one, or maybe both of them, two outsiders took everybody on Wall Street for a ride.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Yes, it really looks like they did.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER MUDD
dialogues.text: And Acosta has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: With hundreds of millions of dollars.  118.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER MUDD
dialogues.text: Kenny Wells has consistently maintained his innocence, that he was duped along with everyone else. Given that, what do you make of this? He picks up a copy of NEWSWEEK MAGAZINE -- Kenny Wells on cover. Mudd reads the caption out loud: ROGER MUDD (CONT’D) “Kenny Wells - Fool or Mastermind?" ».-Care to comment? Off Hancock, maybe for the first time, he’s at a loss...

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: That is a very good question, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MONTAGE of time passing. Wells in the suite on the phon Wells at an increasingly empty Washoe headquarters. Wells increasingly desperate, then finally hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells stands on the steps in front of the building, a hun MICROPHONES and CAMERAS in his face. NEWS VANS jam the sidewalk. A mob of ANGRY PROTESTORS held at bay by POLICE

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Mike Acosta was my friend and partner and he betrayed me. I had no knowledge of the deception he perpetrated. As CEO of this company, it was my job to know. I take full responsibility for my failure in this regard and I apologize sincerely to those who have lost their investments. Wherever you are, Mike, it’s time to come in. Tell what happened... Mike --? He can’t go on. Finally, he chokes out -- WELLS (CONT’D) That’s all I have to say at this time. The assembled reporters shout out a flurry of questions a Wells's back as he leaves. They pursue him. Surrounding h car. Trying to stop him from pulling out.  119. EXT. HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - RENO - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells pulls in. Crowds out front waiting for him. INT. HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - RENO - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry FRONT DESK GUY trying to talk about the bill.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GUY
dialogues.text: Mr. Wells, when exactly will you be departing? People hearing his name. Crowds turning. Pouring in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors closing out the faces of angry, shouting people Wells just shuts his eyes and rides in blessed silence. DING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells checks the hallway both directions. AT THE “PROSPECTOR SUITE” Checks hall again. Uses his key to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells entering, motoring toward the bar, freezes. Finds:

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, BANKS, AND LEVINE
dialogues.text: Waiting for him like executioners on execution day. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Do I need a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Do you need a lawyer? A moment between poker players. Then Wells shakes his hea JENNINGS (CONT’D) Right answer. Jennings posts two guards outside the door. Sets the tape recorder on the table. Wells at the bar searching, findin stashed bottle.  120.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: .«.--Sure I can’t pour you one?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I’m working.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: All the more reason.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Wells, sit down. We’ve got a lot to cover... The same exchange that started the film. Time has caught with Kenny Wells’ storytelling.

dialogues.speaker: SLOW FADE IN
dialogues.text: The Golden Pickaxe STATUE catching morning sun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sierra Nevada out the windows. It’s fall.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER OVER
dialogues.text: Wells facing Jennings, listening.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I think it’s pretty unlikely we'll ever see your partner again.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Wait, what do you mean? You're not telling me something. What happened to Mike?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: A lot of very powerful people are very angry at Michael Acosta.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: What happened! ? Jennings searches Wells's face again for a trace of the disingenuous.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: What happened? Yes. That’s what we’re trying to put together. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seventeen billion dollars of value disappeared overnight. That is certain. What else? Michael Acosta waves goodbye to you in the ballroom downstairs -- ta-ta -- goes back to Indonesia on a jet chartered with Washoe funds, and then he does his disappearing act. This you know... Off Wells -- PRE-LAP: The sound of HELICOPTER ROTORS, growing louder. Deafening

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A helicopter chops at the morning air -- flying in low ov the lush jungle as the sun is about to rise.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: First, he’s locked out of the assay lab in Kalimantan by The Minister of the Interior. So he goes back to Jakarta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta emerges from a plane and walks down the gangway st

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where he is immediately detained by Indonesian Military. Waiting for him at the bottom are INDONESIAN SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: (subtitled) This way Mr. Acosta.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And they hold him while they try to reproduce for themselves the lab results claimed by Washoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta watching men march in formation through a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which of course they are unable to do.  122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennings takes his time. He’s enjoying this a little.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: And at this point either he’s being moved to an actual prison, or he’s bribed one of the officers. Either way, he’s on a military helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acosta sits in the hold of the chopper, two soldiers acro from him, a pilot and another SOLDIER up front, all armed

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They fly north loosely tracking the Kensana river. The chopper arcs in, following the river’s course. Acosta stares out, far into the distance, taking in the breathtaking beauty.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do not underestimate the Suharto family. They are gangsters whose turf is a nation of 100 million. Acosta in the back of the chopper. He’s got a six-pack of Tuborg Gold in cans. He cracks one, holds the others out the soldiers, who decline. He drains the beer. He looks d at the river as it passes far below, flashing gold in the sunlight, a snaking golden river, golden dream -- Hands suddenly undo his harness. An involuntary breath. T smile creeps onto his face. Acosta now at the open hatch door of the chopper. Tighter his eyes taking it in. He’s coming home.

dialogues.speaker: IN SILENCE MIKE ACOSTA FALLS FROM THE HELICOPTER
dialogues.text: Falling and falling and falling toward canpoy and water -  123.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A thousand feet up, over the Kensana, Mike Acosta takes a header. ON THE PILOT -- as he turns and looks back and sees the E SEAT, the soldiers buckling back in. He turns back around ACOSTA POV of ONRUSHING RIVER. CLOSER AND CLOSER AND THEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells is on the edge of his seat, eyes red from lack of s booze, cigarette smoke. He’s shaken up by the news. He do want to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: No way. No fucking way. Mike was too good, too savvy. He had to be planning this. He knows what they do to you for salting. What you think they’d do. He faked it. Or he paid just to have the story out. (desperate) 164 million goes a long way in Indonesia...

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: (beat) They found a body.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Are you sure it’s him?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I’m not sure of anything, except Mike Acosta traded water filters for river gold, but now the Indonesian government has gone unusually quiet on the subject and seems to have, publicly at least, lost all interest in finding Michael Acosta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CRANE SHOT of the INDONESIAN MILITARY and DAYAK in se circle around the SPLAYED BODY. One of the soldiers breaks ranks and moves forward, kneel by the body. What he sees there sickens him --  124.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Hands and face were eaten away. Probably by wild pigs. BANG. All heads whirl. The BIG SNAKE FALLS. Floats down r The soldier finds the wallet, flips it open, checks the I And this time we see the name -- MICHAEL ACOSTA. And a picture of MIKE ACOSTA, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There was an autopsy, corroborating the identity with dental records from Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennings produces documents with a sort of bemused skepti Autopsy. Photos of a pig-eaten body. Affidavit of cremati

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Then they sealed the report, cremated the remains. Interestingly Danny Suharto dumped a lot of stock as well. So the Suhartos are even richer, Mike Acosta is ostensibly dead and buried, a hundred sixty four million is still missing, and the question I’m left with is whether or not you were in on it? Wells takes a moment. Slowly shakes his head. Sad.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Can't believe what? Wells eyes well up. He rubs at them, making them even red He lights a cig to cover the emotions.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: ...Everyone in the business had written him off, called his theories crap, and he couldn’t let that be the last word on him.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: You talking about Acosta or yourself? Wells ignores that.  125.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: We were running out of money and I was sick with Malaria, I think that’s when the salting started. Mike was sure he was right, the gold was there, but he needed to buy us more time to find it. I don’t think he set out to swindle anyone, but by the time he realized he was wrong and there was no gold, he was in too deep. I honestly think he just didn’t want to let me down. And I was fooled just like everybody else. A pregnant beat. Levine, Jennings’ underling, leans down. saying something that is mostly muffled... “Either world’ biggest fool or...”

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: ..-he’s not telling the truth --

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: The truth!? The only truth here is that when everyone’s getting rich nobody gives a shit about the truth. All anyone had to do was look. Open their eyes. The gold was wrong. The find was too good. Red flags everywhere, but no one looked, because no one wanted to know. Not me, not you, not anyone. What we all wanted was to believe. Why? Because we were making so much money. Jennings looks over at Banks and Levine. That landed.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: (to his coworkers) Mark, Eric, sit down please. Jennings checks the cassette on the tape recorder. And wh addresses his questions to Wells we can feel it’s all com down to this. JENNINGS (CONT’D) Were you aware that Mike Acosta was salting the Washoe core samples?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: You had no knowledge Mike Acosta was perpetrating a fraud?  126.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: No. I thought I’d won the lottery.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: You were not in collusion with Mike Acosta on the Kensana gold strike?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Did you profit from the Kensana fraud?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: You know I didn’t. I can’t pay the hotel bill. Hell, I can’t even get the minibar.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Did anyone close to you profit?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: You have gained nothing?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: My friends lost money, my neighbors lost money, but I lost everything. Because, the real truth is... I never cared much about money. I cared about gold. It’s different, Jennings. It’s different. Jennings, Banks, and Levine walk away and confer. It’s cl they’re having a difficult time reaching a quorum. Wells turns and looks at the mountains. And then Jennings crosses back.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: (into tape recorder) End of deposition, 6:45 AM, Seventeen, October, 1988, conducted by Paul K. Jennings - Special Agent In Charge, Federal Bureau of Investigation, District of Nevada, Reno. He presses stop on the recorder. Closes his notes. He and Wells look at each other a long moment. JENNINGS (CONT’D) You're free to go, Mr. Wells.  127. Wells seems like he wasn’t expecting this and maybe almos like he was past caring about it.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Look at that, somebody believes me.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t go overboard. In fact, I wouldn’t leave the state. Wouldn’t start buying new stuff or chartering any more jets.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I gotta sneak out of here without the front desk guy seeing me. You picking up that tab?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: It’s been quite a whirlwind, hasn’t it, Mr. Wells? Wells has no fucking idea how to even begin to answer tha one. As the coworkers leave --

dialogues.speaker: BANKS
dialogues.text: Good luck, Mr. Wells

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: We'll be keeping an eye out for you. Jennings starts to leave, then pauses --

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now, Wells? And as we push in on Wells, we can see deep in his eyes t beginnings of a plan... EXT. PARKING LOT - HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - MORNING Wells looks back at the hotel. He sees two red-tailed haw perched on a balcony rail. They drop in unison and then r on a warm draft. Wells watches them rise and rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is placed on the passenger seat of his car. Wells smoking Driving. Flicks ashes at the ashtray, misses by a mile.  128. Through the glass, a familiar, neater house appears. EXT. KAY’S HOUSE - DAY He pulls into the driveway of Kay’s house. The car shuts He gathers himself. Picks up the rose. Gets out of the ca Hart Hubbard, pruning a bush, stops snipping.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Kenny, I’m still worried about that mulberry over the back fence. An old Mulberry tree grows over the shared fence. Wells doesn’t need to look.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I know. Good to see you, Hart.

dialogues.speaker: HART HUBBARD
dialogues.text: Good to see you too, Kenny. He’s at the door. He takes a breath and knocks. After a w he hears footsteps. Then the door opens. Revealing KAY. S looks at the single flower. At Wells.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: Can I come in? Kay considers a beat longer than is comfortable, then ste aside to let him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wells sees the pool has been fixed and filled. It sparkle Wells sitting at the dinette looking at Kay. She looks at A golden light shines through new curtains above the sink

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I made curtains.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: The house looks great. And so do you. Kay puts the flower in a small vase. She puts two coffee on the dinette. She looks at him a moment then shakes her head. Wells takes a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WELLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I called up Carl.  129.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You called Carl? (beat) What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: I think he was surprised to hear from me. He’ll see me next week. No promises.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Wait, you really called him?

dialogues.speaker: WELLS
dialogues.text: (beat) No... Not yet. But I’m going to. She starts to laugh. He starts to laugh. He reaches out h hand to hold hers across the table. They look at each oth WELLS (CONT’D) Goddamn. And then they laugh at the absurdity of it all, of life, trying to make sense of any of it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Oh, some stuff came for you. Some mail. She goes and finds a grocery bag of stuff that’s come for He dumps it on the table, searching past catalogues and t share opportunities, until he finds what he’s looking for

dialogues.speaker: A FOREIGN ENVELOPE
dialogues.text: Thin and light blue with PAR AVION stamped on it. Wells looks at it. He looks at Kay. Then he takes out a s pocket knife, uses the short blade to slice it open. He extracts... an old napkin. THE NAPKIN. The one he and Acosta signed in the jungle. He unfolds it He reads: Prove ‘em all wrong. “50-50" Whatever it takes...  130. Followed by two faded signatures: Kenny Wells & Mike Acos He stares at Mike’s signature a long moment, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his name, at THE FIRST BANK OF GIBRALTAR, exactly half Acosta sold, fifty percent. He looks up at Kay mysteriously. And he smiles.
